APPLIED ,~ ~, ~~i. ~.,~::~ C ATALY Si S A: GENERAL ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 99 112 Reductive amination of ethanol with silica- supported cobalt and nickel catalysts Gary Sewell *, Cyril O'Connor, Eric van Steen Catalysis Research Unit, Department of Chemical Engineering, UniversiO' of Cape Town, Pritate Bag, Rondebosch, 7700, South Africa Received 27 July 1994: revised 23 December 1994: accepted 3 January 1995 Abstract The amination of ethanol has been studied using silica-supported cobalt and nickel catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. Under identical operating conditions, the Co/SiO2 catalyst is considerably more active for ethanol conversion than the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, in spite of the lower measured metal surface area. The higher activity of the Co/SiO2 catalyst combined with its higher selectivity towards the industrially desired lower amines (MEA and DEA) make the metal a promising catalyst. Selectivity to individual ethylamine products (i.e. mono-, di- and triethylamine) is kinetically controlled and a function of the operating parameters as well as of the metal catalyst employed. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR), temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) and hydrogen chemisorption have been used to characterize the physico-chemical differences between the catalysts used in this study. Keywords: Cobalt: Ethanol amination; Nickel 1. Introduction Ethylamines find considerable industrial application, especially as reactants in the synthesis of industrial chemical intermediates and end products. Monoethylam- ine is used in the synthesis of herbicides, corrosion inhibitors and wash and wear agents for fabrics, diethylamine is used in the synthesis of rubber processing chem- icals, pharmaceuticals and epoxy curing agents and triethylamine is used in the production of textile treating chemicals, insecticides and antibiotics [1,2]. Mon- oethylamine is manufactured in the largest quantities by the organic synthesis industry. * Corresponding author. E-mail gs@chemeng.uct.ac.za, tel. General 125 (1995) 99- l 12 Among several methods which have been proposed for the synthesis of ethyla- mines [2], the reductive amination of ethanol has gained considerable importance [3]. Although a number of supported metals have been applied for the reductive amination of alcohols [2], nickel and cobalt appear to be the preferred catalysts for industrial application [ 1,4-7 ]. The reductive amination of ethanol using cobalt has been studied using supports such as alumina [ 1,4], kieselguhr [ 1 ], silica and zeolite Y [6] whilst the performance of nickel has been investigated using supports such as silica [4], alumina and kieselguhr [ 1 ]. A silica supported nickel-rhenium catalysts has also been shown to be an efficient catalyst for the amination of ethanol using ammonia [7]. The product from this commercial process typically comprises an equilibrium controlled distribution of ethylamines, the ratios of which can be altered by adjust- ing the feed ratio or the reaction temperature [8]. No study, however, has yet been presented which compares the performance of cobalt and nickel catalysts over a range of operating conditions. This paper presents the results of a study comparing the performance of silica- supported cobalt (Co/SiO2) and nickel (Ni/SiO2) catalysts for the amination of ethanol. In particular, the effect of varying space velocity, hydrogen pressure, ammonia pressure and reaction temperature are reported. Physico-chemical char- acterization of the catalysts was used as a basis for comparison of the observed differences in catalytic performance. 2. Experimental 2.1. Catalyst preparation The Co/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts used in this study were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of silica gel (May and Baker) using an aqueous solution of the corresponding metal nitrate. The concentrations of the impregnating solutions were adjusted so as to give metal loadings of 10 wt.-% after activation of the catalyst. The support employed was silica gel with a measured N2 BET surface area of 725 m2/g. The metal salts used, viz. Co(NO3)2 "6H20 and Ni(NO3)2' 6H20, were analytical grade reagents (99% minimum purity) and were supplied by Merck. Following impregnation, the catalysts were dried at 100 for a period of 16 h before storage in a desiccator. 2.2. Catalyst characterization Reduction behaviours of the catalysts were obtained using a temperature pro- grammed reduction (TPR) apparatus constructed of stainless steel valves and fittings and containing a quartz microreactor. Prior to reduction, the catalyst ( ~ 0.15 g) was calcined in 60 ml(NTP)/min air at 500 for 3 h in order to decompose G. Sewell et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 125 (1995) 99-112 101 the nitrate precursor. Reduction was performed in a 60 ml(NTP)/min 5% H2/N2 stream as the temperature was raised linearly from 100 to 1000 at 10/min. Before entry into the thermal conductivity detector (TCD), the reductant stream was fed through a 3A molecular sieve trap to remove water formed by metal oxide reduction. 60 ml (NTP)/min of nitrogen was used as a TCD reference stream and hydrogen consumptions were recorded as differences in thermal conductivity between the two streams. Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) studies were performed in the same apparatus as used for temperature programmed reduction. The procedure involved calcination of the catalyst sample ( = 0.15 g) in 60 mI(NTP)/min air at 500 for 3 h followed by reduction in 60 ml(NTP)/min 5% Hz/N2 at 500 for 3 h (i.e. the procedure used to activate the catalysts used for reaction studies). After reduc- tion, the catalyst sample was cooled to 50. Temperature programmed oxidation of the reduced catalyst was performed in a 30 ml/min 2% O2/He stream as the temperature was raised linearly from 50 to 1000 at 10/rain. 30 mI(NTP)/min helium was used as the TCD reference stream and oxygen consumptions were recorded as differences in thermal conductivity between the two streams. Metal surface area determinations were performed in a conventional Pyrex glass volumetric adsorption apparatus using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 chemisorption apparatus. The procedure involved precalcination of the catalyst sample ( ~ 0.5 g) in 60 mI(NTP)/min air at 500 for 3 h followed by reduction in 60 ml(NTP)/ rain hydrogen at 500 for 3 h. The reduced catalyst was cooled to 400 and evacuated until the pressure was less than 1 10 3 torr. The reduced catalyst samples were then cooled under vacuum and the hydrogen adsorption isotherms were measured between 300 and 450 torr at 100 for the Co/SiO2 catalyst [9] and at 25 for the Ni/SiO2 catalyst [ 10]. 2.3. Ethanol amination The gas phase amination of ethanol was studied in an atmospheric, continuous flow reactor with on-line gas chromatographic detection of reaction products (Fig. 1 ). Sampling of reactant and product gases was performed using a six-way valve and the samples were analyzed using a Varian Model 3700 gas chromatograph equipped with thermal conductivity detector. The separation was achieved using a 4 m 3 mm ID glass column packed with 60/80 mesh Carbopack B/4% Carbowax 20M/0.8% KOH. Nitrogen was used as an internal standard allowing mass balances to be determined to within 5%. Prior to the experiment, the catalyst precursor (2.00 g) was calcined in 100 ml (NTP)/min air at 500 for 3 h and then cooled to 100 before reduction. The reduction was performed in 100 ml(NTP)/min of a 20% H2/N2 gas mixture at 500 for 3 h. After cooling in nitrogen to 100, the reactor was switched to bypass and the feed delivery system was stabilized. Temperature programmed reduction Reduction behaviours of both the supported as well as the unsupported oxides of nickel and cobalt were investigated using temperature programmed reduction. Both supported catalysts exhibited large extents of metal support interaction which influenced metal reducibility. This factor is of considerable importance in this study since only metal reducible by 500 is available for reductive amination. A maxi- mum reduction temperature of 500 was chosen in order to minimize sintering whilst still obtaining a high extent of reduction. The TPR spectrum of the Co/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 2) showed both the low tem- perature reduction of Co304 at 350 as well as the reduction of various cobalt- silicate species [ 11-13] at higher temperatures. Measurement of the hydrogen consumption during temperature programmed reduction of the Co/SiO2 catalyst to 1000 showed that 1.14 mmol of hydrogen was required to reduce 1 mmol of cobalt (assuming complete reduction up to 1000). It thus appears that the cobalt is present as a mixture of divalent and trivalent cobalt species. To determine the extent of reduction of the Co/SiO2 catalyst, temperature programmed oxidation of the activated catalyst (calcined and reduced at 500) was performed. The oxygen consumption corresponding to oxidation of reduced cobalt metal showed that only 35% of the cobalt had been reduced by 500 (assuming oxidation of reduced cobalt to Co304). Since complete reduction of an unsupported bulk cobalt oxide occurs by 500, it is clear that metal-support interactions decrease the reducibility of silica supported cobalt. Temperature programmed reduction of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 3) shows a broad single reduction step similar to the reduction of bulk NiO. The increase in 104 G. The higher metal surface area of the Ni/SiO2 catalyst is due to a greater extent of reduction (as shown from the TPO results) and a higher metal dispersion. The lower metal dispersion obtained for the Co/SiO2 catalyst is surprising since increasing metal-support interaction is expected to stabilize smaller metal crystallites. Taking into account that the amount of reduced metal as well as the metal dispersion is higher for the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, it is evident that the turnover number of the supported nickel catalyst is lower than that of the supported cobalt catalyst. The reductive amination of alcohols has been proposed to be a set of reversible series reactions [ 3,18,19 ] as illustrated below (R=H, alkyl ). RCH2OH ~ RCH=O + H2 (l) RCH=O + NH3 ~ RCH=NH + H20 (2) RCH=NH + H2 ~ RCH2NH2 (3) RCH=O + RCH2NH2 ~ RCH=NCH2R + H20 (4) RCH=NCHzR + H2 ~ (RCH~_)2NH (5) RCH=O + (RCH2) 2NH + H2 ~ (RCH2) 3N 4- H20 (6) The initial step in the amination process involves the reversible dehydrogenation of the alcohol to give the intermediate aldehyde. This dehydrogenation involves the abstraction of an a-hydrogen from the alcohol and has been found to be the rate determining step for the amination of ethanol with ammonia [20] as well as the amination of octanol using monomethylamine [ 3,18 ]. Condensation of the alde- hyde with ammonia (or a product amine) forms an intermediate imine which may be hydrogenated to form the product alkylamine. It can therefore be concluded that the overall rate of ethanol dehydrogenation (Reaction 1) occurs more rapidly on the Co/SiO2 catalyst as compared to the Ni/SiO2 catalyst. Attempts to observe the postulated ethanal intermediate in this study were unsuccessful. The monoethylamine (MEA) selectivity decreases and the diethylamine (DEA) and triethylamine (TEA) selectivities increase with increasing ethanol conversion for both the Co/SiO2 and the Ni/SiO2 catalysts. This observation is in agreement with the series nature of the reductive amination reaction. At high ethanol conver- sions (i.e. low ethanol space velocity), the ethylamine selectivities approach the thermodynamically predicted values (MEA:DEA:TEA = 17:50:33 ). Comparison of the individual ethylamine selectivities at identical conversions of ethanol shows that the MEA selectivity is lower and the DEA and TEA selectivities are higher when using the Ni/SiO2 catalyst as opposed to the Co/SiO2 catalyst. In a reversible series reaction where the first step is the slowest in the sequence, a decrease in the rate of the first step allows more time for the products formed in the sequential processes to reach equilibrium (at identical conversions of the first species). This data supports the previous observation that the rate of dehydroge- nation of ethanol is slower on the Ni/SiO2 catalyst in comparison to the Co/SiO2 catalyst. G. Although the mechanism of formation of diethylether is uncertain, it might be due to an acid catalysed condensation of ethanol by support silanol groups. MEA content increases whilst DEA and TEA contents decrease within the fraction of ethylamines with decreasing partial pressures of hydrogen. It thus appears that hydrogen is required for the sequential conversion of MEA to DEA and TEA. This is consistent with the postulated reaction mechanism where the imine intermediate must first be hydrogenated to form the amine before further reaction can occur. The higher MEA selectivities obtained when using the Co/SiO2 catalyst can thus pos- sibly be ascribed to the lower hydrogenation activity of cobalt as compared to nickel. Since the slowest step during the amination of ethanol appears to be the dehydrogenation of ethanol (i.e. not involv- ing ammonia), the decrease in ethanol conversion might be due to increased cobalt and nickel nitride formation with increasing ammonia partial pressure. Since reductive amination is a series reaction, this implies that the reaction is largely kinetically controlled under the conditions employed in this study. 4. Conclusions Silica-supported cobalt has been shown to be a more active catalyst for the amination of ethanol using ammonia than a silica-supported nickel catalyst, in spite of a lower active metal surface area caused by the formation of inactive metal- support compounds. It can therefore be concluded that the net overall rate of ethanol dehydrogenation, which has been shown to be the slowest step during ethanol amination [20], is greater when using a cobalt catalyst than a nickel catalyst. Under the conditions used in this study, the cobalt catalyst also had a higher yield of the industrially desired less substituted amines (MEA and DEA) and produced little unwanted byproduct, thus making the metal a promising amination catalyst. With the nickel catalyst, a further extent of the series substitution of monoethylamine was observed. The actual product composition can be adjusted by changing the reaction parameters to obtain the desired product spectrum. Tel. (+27-21) 6502518, fax (+27-21) 6503775 The amination of ethanol has been studied using silica-supported cobalt and nickel catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. Under identical operating conditions, the Co/SiO2 catalyst is considerably more active for ethanol conversion than the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, in spite of the lower measured metal surface area. The higher activity of the Co/SiO2 catalyst combined with its higher selectivity towards the industrially desired lower amines (MEA and DEA) make the metal a promising catalyst.
